repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
#4160

This essentially treats C++ variables as Python variables, where they can be bound or unbound, and stack allocated variables don't need a default constructor any more. This feature needs C++17 (or boost optional) and so is off by default.

It work with globals, class attributes, and locals. Untested on closure variables currently.

Long-term I'd like to run (pretty much) the entire C++ test-suite with this turned on for at least one Python version - i.e. almost everything that works in C++ mode should work with this. I'm not sure if this is feasible though - the following code (which is in the utility code) doesn't work (correctly)

```
cdef convert(list l):
    cdef vector[int] vec  # not initialized
    for item in l:
        vec.push_back(item)
    return vec
```

I think this is fine - but it does make it hard to test in bulk

comment_data.body:
Currently breaks a few C++ tests - to be dealt with properly in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4206.

Edit: can probably be reverted actually - the utility code will end up using the "cpp_locals" directive, but should work either way hopefully so it isn't a huge practical problem.

comment_data.body: I promise this line removal is undone on the version on my hard-disk. It just doesn't seem worth rerunning the tests for it until there are other changes.

It helps readability if special words stick out of the normal reading flow.
```suggestion
            # The Python 2.7 headers contain the 'register' modifier
            # which clang warns about in C++17 mode.
            ext.extra_compile_args.append('-Wno-register')
```

+        if sys.version_info[0] < 3:
+            ext.extra_compile_args.append('-Wno-register')  # the Python 2.7 headers contain register
+                # which clang warns about with C++17 on

+# mode: run
+# tag: cpp, cpp17

+cimport cython

+cdef extern from *:
+    """
+    class C {
+        public:
+            C() = delete; // look! No default constructor
+            C(int x) : x(x) {}
+
+            int getX() const { return x; }
+
+        private:
+            int x;
+    };
+
+    C make_C(int x) {
+        return C(x);

+        C(int)
+        int getX() const

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -629,6 +634,43 @@ utility can be used to generate a C++ ``.cpp`` file, and then compile it
 into a python extension.  C++ mode for the ``cython`` command is turned
 on with the ``--cplus`` option.
 
+.. _cpp_locals directive:
+
+``cpp_locals`` directive
+========================
+
+The ``cpp_locals`` compiler directive is an experimental feature that makes
+C++ variables behave like normal Python object variables.  With this
+directive they are only initialized at their first assignment, and thus
+they no longer require a nullary constructor to be stack-allocated. Trying to
+access an uninitialized C++ variable will generate an ``UnboundLocalError``
+(or similar) in the same way as a Python variable would. For example::
+
+    def function(dont_write):
+        cdef SomeCppClass c  # not initialized
+        if dont_write:
+            return c.some_cpp_function()  # UnboundLocalError
+        else:
+            c = SomeCppClass(...)  # initialized
+            return c.some_cpp_function()  # OK
+            
+Additionally the directive avoids initializing temporary C++ objects before
+they are assigned, for cases where Cython needs to use such objects in its
+own code-generation (often for return values of functions that can throw
+exceptions).
+
+For extra speed, the ``initializedcheck`` directive disables the check for an
+unbound-local. With this directive on, accessing a variable that has not
+been initialized will trigger undefined behaviour, and it is entirely the user's
+responsibility to avoid such access.
+
+The ``cpp_locals`` directive is currently implemented using ``std::optional``
+and thus requires a C++17 compatible compiler. Defining
+``CYTHON_USE_BOOST_OPTIONAL`` (as define for the C++ compiler) uses ``boost::optional``
+instead (but is even more experimental and untested). The directive does
+come with a memory and performance cost due to the need to store and check 
+a boolean that tracks if a variable is initialized.

comment_data.body:
> but the C++ compiler should be able to eliminate the check in most cases.

I think Cython (rather than the C++ compiler) eliminates the check in the more obvious cases. But that probably doesn't matter for the documentation.

comment_data.body:
This looks like an entirely separate method, maybe `cpp_optional_declaration_code()`. It could raise `NotImplementedError` and be overridden only in `CppClassType`.

Alternatively, the `Entry` could  also have a method `declaration_code()` (or maybe `var_declaration_code()` to make it stick out), which would call its type's methods normally and do the above dance if it's declared as C++ optional.

comment_data.body: `null_code` sounds like we're overriding the code for `NULL` here, not a complete null check. Let's name it `unbound_check_code`, even if it's a bit longer. It's not the callers concern that "unbound" is defined as being `NULL`.

comment_data.body:
I hadn't noticed that we're doing this in two places.
```suggestion
            # Override directives that should not be inherited from user code.
            # TODO: filter directives with an allow list to keep only those that are safe and relevant.
            directives = dict(env.directives, cpp_locals=False)```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3135,6 +3135,31 @@ def visit_Node(self, node):
         return node
 
 
+class CoerceCppTemps(EnvTransform, SkipDeclarations):
+    """
+    For temporary expression that are implemented using std::optional it's necessary the temps are
+    assigned using `__pyx_t_x = value;` but accessed using `something = (*__pyx_t_x)`. This transform
+    inserts a coercion node to take care of this, and runs absolutely last (once nothing else can be
+    inserted into the tree)
+
+    TODO: a possible alternative would be to split ExprNode.result() into ExprNode.rhs_rhs() and ExprNode.lhs_rhs()???
+    """
+    def visit_ModuleNode(self, node):
+        if self.current_env().cpp:
+            # skipping this makes it essentially free for C files
+            self.visitchildren(node)
+        return node
+
+    def visit_ExprNode(self, node):
+        self.visitchildren(node)
+        if (self.current_env().directives['cpp_locals'] and
+                node.is_temp and node.type.is_cpp_class):
+            node = ExprNodes.CppOptionalTempCoercion(node)
+
+        return node
+

comment_data.body:
Could you merge this into `code.put_error_if_unbound()` ? As well as the attribute error raising further down?

It already does some similar checks and then leaves the error raising to a utility function. I think it's good to have a single place for all of these errors. Better than handling some there and some in-place.

(Note that I just moved some of these utility functions into utility code files in the master branch as a cleanup. You can build on that.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2342,12 +2342,26 @@ def generate_result_code(self, code):
             # Raise UnboundLocalError for objects and memoryviewslices
             raise_unbound = (
                 (self.cf_maybe_null or self.cf_is_null) and not self.allow_null)
-            null_code = entry.type.check_for_null_code(entry.cname)
 
             memslice_check = entry.type.is_memoryviewslice and self.initialized_check
+            optional_cpp_check = entry.is_cpp_optional and self.initialized_check
 
-            if null_code and raise_unbound and (entry.type.is_pyobject or memslice_check):
-                code.put_error_if_unbound(self.pos, entry, self.in_nogil_context)
+            if optional_cpp_check:
+                unbound_check_code = entry.type.cpp_optional_check_for_null_code(entry.cname)
+            else:
+                unbound_check_code = entry.type.check_for_null_code(entry.cname)
+
+            if unbound_check_code and raise_unbound and (entry.type.is_pyobject or memslice_check or optional_cpp_check):
+                code.put_error_if_unbound(self.pos, entry, self.in_nogil_context, unbound_check_code=unbound_check_code)
+
+        elif entry.is_cglobal and entry.is_cpp_optional and self.initialized_check:
+            null_code = entry.type.cpp_optional_check_for_null_code(entry.cname)
+            code.putln(
+                'if (unlikely(!%s)) {'
+                    'PyErr_SetString(PyExc_NameError,'
+                                    '"C++ global \'%s\' is not initialized");'
+                    '%s'
+                '}' % (null_code, self.name, code.error_goto(self.pos)))

     Note: in order to support cross-closure type inference, this must be
     applies to nested scopes in top-down order.
     """
-    def set_entry_type(self, entry, entry_type):
+    def set_entry_type(self, entry, entry_type, scope):
         for e in entry.all_entries():
             e.type = entry_type
             if e.type.is_memoryviewslice:
                 # memoryview slices crash if they don't get initialized
                 e.init = e.type.default_value
+            if e.type.is_cpp_class:
+                if scope.directives['cpp_locals']:
+                    e.make_cpp_optional()
+                else:
+                    e.type.check_nullary_constructor(entry.pos)
+

commit.message: This seems to work a little better I think maybe
Basic example looks to be working
Removed some transforms in favour of scope picking type

cpp_locals_nocheck -> initializedcheck

since it already exists, so there's no reason to add an extra
directive. It can now be applied as locally as required

-Wno-register on clang

Hopefully fixes OS X on Python 2.7

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Handle c++ variables using std::optional
